description.narrative: Stöd till regeringen i Mocambique via UN Joint Program (implementerat av UNICEF och ILO) för att förbättra täckningen och kvalitet av det nationella sociala trygghetssystemet. Programmet som nu går in I sin andra fas fokuserar på att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten på den genomförande myndigheten INAS och på ansvarigt ministerium, ministeriet för jämställdhet, barn och social trygghet (MGCAS). Sverige kommer att i dialog med regeringen (främst via ovan nämnda institutioner) arbeta för ökad täckning av mottagare av regelbundet utbetalda kontantstöd samt för en ökning av beloppen som betalas ut.

Support to the Government of Mozambique via the UN Joint Programme (implemented by UNICEF and ILO) to increase the coverage and quality of the social protection system. The program, commencing its second phase, will focus on strenghtening the institutional capacity at the implementing national agency INAS and at the responsible ministry, Ministry for Gender, Children and Social Action, MGCAS. Sweden will in its dialogue with the government (mainly with the above mentions national structures) work for an increased coverage of beneficiaries for regularly paid social cash transfers as well as an increase of the cash transfers' amounts.

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

tag.narrative: 1.3 - Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1.3 - Införa nationellt lämpliga system och åtgärder för socialt skydd för alla, inklusive grundskydd, och senast 2030 säkerställa att de omfattar en väsentlig andel av de fattiga och de utsatta.

title.narrative: Agreement UN Joint Programme Social Protection
Agreement amendment One UN Joint programme on Social Protection
Decision on Agreement amendment One UN Joint Programme on Social Protection
Decision on Contribution UN Joint Programme Social Protection

description.narrative:
2019 was the second full year of implementation and was a year for consolidating existing processes and activities. Outcome 1 Programme and policy design Which contributes to the design of national social protection programmes. After a long consultative process, the first draft of the PSSB operational manual was produced and jointly reviewed by government and social protection partners. Another key result is the completion of the first stage of the ProSAS (Programa Serviços Sociais de Acção Social, approved by Decree 47/2018) design which includes a country wide social action services directory and an interactive geo-referenced map, which are already available to all stakeholders. Progress was also made in building the INAS monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system, and by the end of 2019, all INAS delegations had full capacity to deliver M&E information through a formal and fully established system which was approved and endorsed by INAS.
Outcome 2: Robust evidence and advocacy The UNJP started to generate evidence for the Child Grant 0-2 programme through the completion of the baseline study whose findings reinforce that the programme is reaching a poor and vulnerable segment of the population and provide a basis for analysis on social protection including the value of the cash transfer and cash plus care model. The UNJP continued to support key advocacy events and here ILO supported a training in social protection to political parties and journalists, the annual Social Protection Week and a launch of the policy brief: “Towards Universal Social Security for the Elderly in Mozambique”. Both ILO and UNICEF, supported the participation of MGCAS and INAS delegations in international conferences and workshops where the national social protection programmes, including the pilot Child Grant programme were presented. In addition, UNICEF continued to support the development of communication materials for the Child Grant.
Outcome 3: Institutional capacity building which focuses on the implementation of the Child Grant programme and on strengthening the institutional capacity of MGCAS and INAS. The UNJP achieved full implementation of the Child Grant 0-2 pilot and by December 2019 a total of 15,345 beneficiaries were enrolled and receiving payments in all 4 target districts. The implementation of the care component started in 2019 and UNICEF supported the training of trainers in Nampula and training of Permanentes, as a result, 1,707 beneficiaries were triaged during registration and of these 406 cases received in in-depth household assessments and to date 199 case management plans have been developed. Progress was also made on the implementation of the behaviour change communication on the nutrition component in the Child Grant and INAS Permanentes started to deliver key messages on nutrition. A milestone was achieved in relation to e-INAS which is the national Management Information System (MIS) for basic (non-contributory) social protection programmes. After a year of continuous support, 99.8% of households from PSSB and PASP programmes were migrated from the old system (LINDEX) into e-INAS from all 31 Delegations and these beneficiaries are now managed exclusively by e-INAS. The second step to finalise the e-INAS is to complete the beneficiary re-registration process. This is a national process which started in December 2019 and includes new data collection which expands the beneficiary data/profile to include the socio-economic status. ILO continued to support the capacity building of key personnel and 30 INAS delegates received a training in Leadership and Transformation Learning Package on Building and Managing Social Protection Floors (TRANSFORM) and two senior staff completed a social protection course in ILO – ITC in Turin. In addition, ILO supported the capacity development of the M&E INAS delegation staff through planning and training workshops, achieving the milestone of a newly designed M&E system for INAS.
The humanitarian response to the cyclones caused delays in the second year of implementation as attention and decision making on regular social protection issues (such as systems building) were not a priority for the first half of the year. At the same time, the cyclone response was also an opportunity to reassess the importance of social protection, most specifically shock responsive social protection and as such the UNJP priorities changed to support the implementation, learning and preparation for future emergencies. Funds were reprogrammed to finance critical social protection activities in response to the cyclones that hit Mozambique in March (Idai) and April (Kenneth) 2019. These include direct and indirect costs of cash transfers for 2500 households in Cabo Delgado, in close coordination with partners as part of a joint social protection response.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
